text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

text: Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine.

text: Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Patient: You know, it was a little, uh I was really hoping that this would start the numbers to decrease, that was what I was anticipating at the very beginning, but I knew there was a possibility that they would be going up. So just a little disappointed – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - that they have been going up. I think that the thing that kept me most uh calm with it was that they weren’t increasing you know as fast as they were before I went You know a person coming into the study with um, I think it was around four when I really started noticing the stuff going and now we’re somewhere around twenty-eight, twenty-nine. Family Member: Twenty-eight. Patient: Yeah. So you know. But that was (chuckles) Doctor: But it, it has slowed down a little bit, you know we design studies you know, we want things to slow down but really what we want to see is you know, huge and immediate increases. So we always sort of go for the home run and then sometimes you know we might get a single and double, Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
